text: CCDM 32.2.7., Formal Clearance of Publication Items is being revised to remove references to the expedited published guidance program and to reflect current office structure.
) CCDM
and Exhibit
were revised to reflect that items for publication are for review in electronic form. (
) Obsolete titles and office names were removed from CCDM
and CCDM
) Exhibit
was made compliant with Section
of the Rehabilitation Act. (
) References were updated and hyperlinked.

Clearance of Publication Items 32.2.7

) The rules contained in this subsection apply to all Division Chief Counsel offices. Differences in organizational structure, however, may require additional levels of clearance that do not apply to all offices. (

) When preparing a proposed publication for formal clearance, the drafting attorney and the assigned reviewer are responsible for ensuring that the propriate forms have been completed and the necessary components of a publication are present; making sure that the spelling, grammar, pagination, photocopying, and assembly of the clearance package are accurate; that the legal research, research statement, cross-references, citations are accurate and current; and ensuring that the proposed reflects the changes recommended during circulation. (
) See Exhibit
for a check list to assist in the preparation of a publication for formal clearance. Proposed publication items are assembled using Document
, Office of Chief Counsel Executive Correspondence (Orange Folder). (
) Clearance packages are assembled top-to-bottom for each level of as follows: (cid:
) A routing or transmittal slip (transmittal document), addressed to the Associate Chief Counsel (on the cover of the orange folder) (cid:
) Updated Executive Summary (inside orange folder on left hand side) CCDM
, Executive Summary) (cid:
) BIN (inside orange folder on right hand side) (cid:

) Additional material may be attached to the proposed publication item. The tachments, however, should be limited to that likely to be particularly helpful reviewers. The material should be listed on the last page of the BIN as ments. List each item separately rather than as a group of attachments with term such as “court opinions” or “legislative history.” There must be copy of any material that is essential to a clear understanding of the publication such as: (cid:

The at- tachments, however, should be limited to that likely to be particularly helpful to reviewers. The material should be listed on the last page of the BIN as attach- ments. List each item separately rather than as a group of attachments with a term such as “court opinions” or “legislative history.” There must be attached a copy of any material that is essential to a clear understanding of the proposed publication such as:
(cid:

If the message of the publication is that the Service will or will not follow the opinion of the court in that case, include any relevant Action on Decision (AOD); (cid:

32.2 Chief Counsel Publication Handbook
identified by name and CASE-MIS number. Write at the bottom of the first page of this attached item: “As of (date) when forwarded for or when cleared at (clearance level)”; (cid:
) Any nontax statute essential to an understanding of the proposed publica- tion unless the statute is quoted or paraphrased in the publication; (cid:
) Any coordination memorandum; (cid:
) Any “suspend” or “comment” memorandum from Treasury; (cid:
) Pertinent memoranda from Treasury, or other memoranda from the Com- missioner, Chief Counsel, or Associate Chief Counsel, or Division Counsel; (cid:
) Coordination memoranda containing unresolved substantive comments; or (cid:
) Any other information deemed useful to a reviewer. (

) When requested, include behind a background tab, a “red-lined strike-out” copy comparing the clearance version of the item with the circulation version showing where additions and deletions have been made as a result of comments received on circulation. In addition, when requested, include copies of the comments received on circulation. (
) When appropriate, also include a “red-lined strike-out” copy comparing the current version of the proposed publication item to the existing publication that the proposed item is revising. (

) To facilitate moving the publication package, include a draft transmittal document to the Chief Counsel and the Deputy Chief Counsel (Operations) or Deputy Chief Counsel (Technical), as appropriate, from the Associate Chief Counsel. See CCDM
) for the content of this transmittal document. (

) When the orange folder is delivered to the reviewer, send the reviewer an email containing electronic copies of the clearance package documents in the orange folder. The email should contain the proposed publication item, the BIN, the legal memo (if there is one), the executive summary, and the draft transmittal document to the Chief Counsel. Any person who makes changes the electronic copies of the proposed publication item or the BIN should email the changes to the drafting attorney or provide the drafting attorney with a marked-up paper copy reflecting the changes. The marked-up copy reflecting the changes should be returned to the drafting attorney to ensure that the drafting attorney is aware of the changes to the clearance package The drafting attorney should keep all changes made to the proposed publica- tion item or the BIN in the background file and should reflect on the copy the name of the person making the changes and the date of the change. (

) Neither the drafting attorney nor any reviewer is required to approve a proposed publication with which the person disagrees. If the drafting attorney or reviewer disagrees with the proposed publication, the dissenting person should place an asterisk beside the person’s name on page
of the BIN leading to a footnote stating, “Do not agree. See dissent of (insert date)” and place a dissenting memorandum in the clearance package. (

) Dissenting memoranda are not to be prepared indiscriminately because of minor changes in language or composition. A dissenting memorandum should not be prepared when the position of the Service has been clearly established by revenue rulings or by acquiescence in or other agreements to follow court opinions if nothing has occurred to cast doubt on the validity of that position. Dissenting memoranda may be prepared with regard to: Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.
K

Dissenting memoranda are not to be prepared indiscriminately because of minor changes in language or composition. A dissenting memorandum should not be prepared when the position of the Service has been clearly by revenue rulings or by acquiescence in or other agreements to follow court opinions if nothing has occurred to cast doubt on the validity of that position.

page (cid:
) A position not previously established by publication or otherwise, if reason- able persons may disagree (cid:
) An established position, if subsequent events can reasonably be under- stood to undermine that position (

) Because contra arguments must be noted in the BIN, any memorandum dis- senting from a position in a proposed publication, whether written in with it by the drafting attorney or assigned reviewer, must initially be included in the clearance package. The Associate Chief Counsel will decide whether to retain the dissenting memorandum as part of the clearance package to be forward to higher levels of clearance. Whether or not the dissenting memoran- dum is retained, the asterisk and footnote described in CCDM
) may not be deleted without the concurrence of the author of the dissenting memorandum. (

) The text of a proposed publication may refer to another proposed publication that is in process if the two are to be published simultaneously. In these the written reference in the proposed publication item to the companion publi- cation is to “Rev. Rul. [insert number] page , this Bulletin.” Companion proposed publications generally are submitted together for all levels of clearance. (
) A proposed publication may be based on a pending letter ruling request or technical advice. See CCDM
, Letter Rulings, and CCDM

, Technical Advice Memorandum and Technical Expedited Advice Memoranda. In these cases, the drafting attorney of the proposed publication must make certain that when the revenue ruling or revenue procedure has been assigned a number in the IRB, notice of the imminent publication of the matter is given to the appropriate person in the branch in which the letter ruling request or technical advice is pending, together with a copy of the revenue ruling or revenue procedure submitted by the branch to the Bulletin Unit for publication. The copy should be noted to show the number assigned and the number and date of the IRB in which it will be published. Note: Generally, the publication will originate in the branch to which the underlying letter ruling request or technical advice is assigned. (

) Generally, issuance of the underlying letter ruling or technical advice is not delayed pending publication of the item in the IRB or an early drop. In rare cumstances, however, it may be advisable to delay the issuance of the letter ruling or technical advice until after the publication item is available to the public or to consider not ruling on the letter ruling request. These circum- stances could include situations where the issuance of the letter ruling or technical advice prior to publication would give a competitive advantage to a taxpayer or the pending publication will reverse a published position. If the Associate office determines that the letter ruling or technical advice should be delayed, then care must be taken to ensure that the publication is published the IRB or released using the early drop procedures prior to issuing the letter ruling or technical advice.

) Because contra arguments must be noted in the BIN, any memorandum dis- senting from a position in a proposed publication, whether written in with it by the drafting attorney or assigned reviewer, must initially be included in the clearance package. A proposed publication may be based on a pending letter ruling request or technical advice. See CCDM
, Letter Rulings, and CCDM

, Issuing Technical Advice Memorandum and Technical Expedited Advice Memoranda. In these cases, the drafting attorney of the proposed publication must make certain that when the revenue ruling or revenue procedure has been assigned a number in the IRB, notice of the imminent publication of the matter is given to the appropriate person in the branch in which the letter ruling request or technical advice is pending, together with a copy of the revenue ruling or revenue procedure submitted by the branch to the Bulletin Unit for publication.
Generally, the publication will originate in the branch to which the underlying letter ruling request or technical advice is assigned.
Generally, issuance of the underlying letter ruling or technical advice is not delayed pending publication of the item in the IRB or an early drop. In rare cir

cumstances, however, it may be advisable to delay the issuance of the letter ruling or technical advice until after the publication item is available to the public or to consider not ruling on the letter ruling request. These circum

stances could include situations where the issuance of the letter ruling or technical advice prior to publication would give a competitive advantage to a taxpayer or the pending publication will reverse a published position. If the Associate office determines that the letter ruling or technical advice should be delayed, then care must be taken to ensure that the publication is published in the IRB or released using the early drop procedures prior to issuing the letter ruling or technical advice.
Chief Counsel Publication (
) The BIN must state whether the proposed revenue ruling or revenue is consistent with any underlying document such as a letter ruling or a technical advice. See CCDM

, Consistency with Underlying Document. If the position stated in the underlying document is being or changed in the proposed revenue ruling or revenue procedure, the BIN should include a statement concerning whether the taxpayer or appropriate Service official will be advised of the change and, if not, the reason for not doing so should be specified. (

) When in the clearance of a proposed revenue ruling or proposed revenue procedure it appears that a holding in the underlying document will not be followed, the branch that issued the underlying document, if different from branch originating the proposed publication, should be given appropriate timely notification when the issue is settled by publication to allow that to take appropriate action. Appropriate action could include: a. Informing the recipient of the letter ruling or technical advice that the holding is being reconsidered and that further reliance on the letter or memorandum is not justified, b. Waiting to inform the recipient of the underlying document of the eration until a final decision to accept the position of the proposed publication has been made, or c. Suspending action on similar requests pending the final approval of the position in the proposed publication. (

) The decision whether to suspend action on similar requests or to notify the recipient of the underlying letter ruling or technical advice that the issue is being reconsidered is made by the Associate Chief Counsel after discussion with the chief of the branch or a representative of that office. (

) If a holding or position in the underlying communication is reversed or by a revenue ruling or revenue procedure based on it, the addressee of the communication is notified of the change concurrently with publication of the revenue ruling or revenue procedure. (

) All proposed publications are cleared by the Associate Chief Counsel. Proposed publications (except “ministerial publications”) are also referred to the Chief Counsel, the Commissioner, and Treasury for clearance. See
, Ministerial Publication Procedures, “Waiver of Clearance”, for information on ministerial publication items. (

) The BIN is the sole clearance document for proposed publication items. At each level of clearance during the formal clearance of a proposed on the approving office will sign the appropriate line on page
of the BIN. tures (or other documentation of approval as discussed in CCDM
CCDM
) must be obtained before submitting the publication item to next level of clearance. The dates to be shown for each approval are the submitted” and the “date cleared.” (
) After the general circulation comment period has closed, the drafting makes any necessary revisions as discussed in CCDM

, Coordination Counsel and Clearance. After the assigned reviewer approves the revised publication item and the assembled package for formal clearance, the clearance is submitted to the assigned reviewer in the Associate office. After the Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.

a. Informing the recipient of the letter ruling or technical advice that the holding is being reconsidered and that further reliance on the letter or memorandum is not justified, b. Waiting to inform the recipient of the underlying document of the eration until a final decision to accept the position of the proposed publication has been made, or c. Suspending action on similar requests pending the final approval of the position in the proposed publication.
After the general circulation comment period has closed, the drafting attorney makes any necessary revisions as discussed in CCDM

, Coordination and Clearance. After the assigned reviewer approves the revised publication item and the assembled package for formal clearance, the clearance package is submitted to the assigned reviewer in the Associate office. After the
of Publication Items
page in the Associate office approves, the proposed publication is submitted to the Associate Chief Counsel for approval. (
) After approval by the Associate Chief Counsel, the Associate Office submits the publication to the Chief Counsel or delegate for approval. (

) A transmittal document is used to forward the clearance package to the Counsel for approval. The transmittal document addressed to the Chief Counsel explains that the publication has been coordinated with Treasury the Service (if applicable), approved by the Associate Chief Counsel, and is being submitted for approval of the Chief Counsel. The transmittal document also provides the name and telephone number of the contact person to be notified when the Chief Counsel has taken action on the matter. (

) The Chief Counsel (including the Deputy Chief Counsels) may request a briefing or may make changes to the proposed publication item. If the Chief Counsel (or Deputy Chief Counsels) changes the proposed publication item but does not make the changes to an electronic version, the drafting attorney must retrieve the clearance package and make the changes. The drafting attorney MUST prepare a compare version to show the changes requested the Chief Counsel (or Deputy Chief Counsels). The drafting attorney should use the options available in Microsoft Word (e.g., the “track changes” feature with changes in the text instead of the balloons to the side of the text) to produce a compare version (red-lined, strike-out) showing the changes. The drafting attorney MUST print the compare version using a color printer so the red-lined changes are clearly detectable. This will assist the Chief (or Deputy Chief Counsels) to more quickly approve the package. The Associate offices will determine whether they will review the clearance package with the color compare version prior to resubmitting the package to the Chief Counsel. (

) The drafting attorney should provide the Assistant to the Commissioner and the assigned Treasury attorney with a courtesy copy via email when the clearance package goes to the Chief Counsel. Inform both parties in the that the clearance package has moved to the Chief Counsel’s office. (

) Although the Chief Counsel has the authority to approve a proposed publica- tion for the Commissioner, it is customary to obtain separate approval from Assistant to the Commissioner on behalf of the Commissioner. To submit a proposed publication for approval of the Commissioner, the drafting attorney can either attach the publication, related BIN, and Executive Summary to an email addressed to the Assistant to the Commissioner or provide the package (with or without attachments), including the Executive Summary, to the Assistant to the Commissioner. The email, or the transmittal with the package, should inform the Assistant to the Commissioner of the offices the Service that have cleared the publication and of the existence of any issues in the publication that might impact tax administration. The Assistant the Commissioner will signal approval or disapproval of the publication either by return email to the individual who emailed the publication or by signing BIN in the appropriate place. If approval is made by email, the email is to be printed out and attached to the BIN. A separate copy is also retained in the background file for the publication item.

in the Associate office approves, the proposed publication is submitted to the Associate Chief Counsel for approval.
After approval by the Associate Chief Counsel, the Associate Office submits the publication to the Chief Counsel or delegate for approval.

) The drafting attorney should provide the Assistant to the Commissioner and the assigned Treasury attorney with a courtesy copy via email when the clearance package goes to the Chief Counsel. Inform both parties in the email that the clearance package has moved to the Chief Counsel’s office. (

) Although the Chief Counsel has the authority to approve a proposed publica- tion for the Commissioner, it is customary to obtain separate approval from the Assistant to the Commissioner on behalf of the Commissioner. To submit a proposed publication for approval of the Commissioner, the drafting attorney can either attach the publication, related BIN, and Executive Summary to an email addressed to the Assistant to the Commissioner or provide the clearance package (with or without attachments), including the Executive Summary, to the Assistant to the Commissioner. The email, or the transmittal with the package, should inform the Assistant to the Commissioner of the offices within the Service that have cleared the publication and of the existence of any issues in the publication that might impact tax administration. The Assistant to the Commissioner will signal approval or disapproval of the publication either by return email to the individual who emailed the publication or by signing the BIN in the appropriate place. If approval is made by email, the email is to be printed out and attached to the BIN. A separate copy is also retained in the background file for the publication item.
32.2.7.7 (08-11-2004) Commissioner Clearance
Chief Counsel Publication (

) After receiving the approval of the Chief Counsel and the Commissioner, the Associate office sends the proposed publication to the appropriate office in Treasury. Generally, this is accomplished by emailing the documents to the assigned Treasury attorney. (
) Treasury responds by memorandum to the Associate Chief Counsel. This memorandum will state whether Treasury approves, approves with changes, recommends suspension, or has other comments. (

) No proposed publication is to be closed or published based on a telephone from Treasury. Attorneys in Treasury, however, may call the drafting attorney reviewer to discuss the proposed publication. (

) Treasury generally does not have a need for taxpayer specific information in order to review a proposed publication item. If Treasury personnel request taxpayer specific information, such as the administrative file (the Commission- er’s official file) from a particular taxpayer’s case (or excerpts from the file), drafting attorney should discuss with the Treasury official the scope of the request and the extent to which taxpayer specific information can be redacted. The drafting attorney should consider coordinating with branch
or
of Procedure and Administration if there are any questions about the need to redact information from the file. For more information see CCDM

, Administrative Files. Next, the drafting attorney of the publication must secure written approval of the Associate Chief Counsel to grant the request. Upon approval of the request, a copy of the administrative file (or excerpts therefrom) is transmitted to Treasury by memorandum prepared for the signature of the Associate Chief Counsel. (

) If the proposed publication is the subject of either (i) an approval with minor changes, (ii) a comment memorandum, or (iii) a suspend dum, as described below, the drafting attorney and reviewer should, at the direction of the Associate Chief Counsel, first review the memorandum and evaluate whether it agrees with the memorandum. After review, the branch consults with the Associate Chief Counsel. If the conclusion is to disagree with some or all of the points made in the memorandum, Treasury will be as directed by the Associate Chief Counsel to see whether reconciliation can be reached. (

) A comment memorandum from Treasury states that the proposed publication reaches the correct result but requests that a significant revision in rationale, scope, or factual description be made. A suspend memorandum requests that the proposed publication not be issued at all, or at least should not be issued reaching the proposed result. Both of these memoranda can result in revisions so substantial that the proposed publication must go through the entire clearance process again. (

) If reconciliation is made with Treasury, and changes are made to the proposed publication, the Associate Chief Counsel must approve the revised publication item. The Associate Chief Counsel will determine whether the changes are important, substantive changes. If so, the Chief Counsel must also approve revised publication item. If the Associate Chief Counsel determines that the publication item should be sent back to the Chief Counsel to be cleared again, the drafting attorney should prepare a color compare version of the publication item highlighting the important, substantive changes. See CCDM
for instructions for preparing a color compare version. Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.
K

, Administrative Files. Next, the drafting attorney of the publication must secure written approval of the Associate Chief Counsel to grant the request. Upon approval of the request, a copy of the administrative file (or excerpts therefrom) is transmitted to Treasury by memorandum prepared for the signature of the Associate Chief Counsel. (

After review, the branch
Clearance of Publication Items 32.2.7
Treasury must furnish a formal approval memorandum before a project may be forwarded to Media Relations or the Bulletin Unit for early release or publica

tion, respectively. In extraordinary circumstances, however, a publication may be forwarded to Media Relations for early release if the Tax Legislative Counsel, Benefits Tax Counsel, International Tax Counsel, or higher
level Treasury official sends an email approving the publication and expressly autho

rizing its early release. In those circumstances, Treasury must furnish a formal approval memorandum as soon thereafter as possible. The approval email and memorandum are included with the BIN and copies are retained in the back
ground file for the publication item.

Clearance of Publication Items 32.2.7
The CASE-MIS number is correct.
The Initiator and Branch Reviewer information is entered in the Records of Clearance on the BIN. CCDM 32.2.4.2(2)
All applicable coordination entries on the BIN are complete and correct. CCDM 32.2.5.2(7)
The Research Statement is updated and complete. CCDM 32.2.4.2.1.10
The final publication package is assembled in proper order in an orange folder. 32.2.7.2(3)
Additional relevant materials attached at the end of the BIN are provided in the correct sequence and in good quality copy. CCDM 32.2.7.2(4)
An email containing the draft publication, the BIN, the legal memo (if there is one) and the draft transmittal to the Chief Counsel is sent to the reviewer. CCDM 32.2.7.2(8)
The current draft date appears on page one of the publication. CCDM 32.2.3.3.2
The Congressional review of rules procedures have been followed. CCDM 32.2.8.2
